nontrivial and robustness against static perturbations that preserve
the relevant symmetries. Last, we calculated the decay depth of the
surface states, which is estimated to be approximately 30 unit cells in
the bulk. All these observations suggest that Co

Acuboid-shaped bulk single crystal was attached to a Cu wire by silver
paint and used as the working electrode. Figure 2A shows the
corrected linear sweep voltammogram(LSV) curve of the bulk single
is used as the reference, an overpotential of just 300 mV is required to

smaller than that for, nanostructured electrocatalysts with a consid-
erably larger surface area (Fig. 2B), such as (Ni/Co)

of Ni foamand Cu wire with silver paint suggests that the high catalytic
activity of this sample originates from the Co
The catalytic kinetics for oxygen evolution is assessed by analysis of
the corresponding Tafel plots. As shown in Fig. 2C, the resultant Tafel
single crystal is only 74 mV dec
nificantly lower than that of Ni foam (190 mV dec
), despite the fact that the latter two catalysts
have much smaller surface areas. This result indicates the superior
reaction kinetics on the bulk single-crystal catalyst. In addition, it is
interesting to observe that the linear region of the Tafel slope is much
wider than for most reported studies. It is well established that the
Tafel analysis is based on the Butler-Volmer equation under the as-
sumption of constant coverage of the intermediate species. However,
both surface coverage of the intermediate species and the reaction
the rapid increase of the Tafel slope in the high-overpotential range.
For Pt in 1 MKOH, this value increases from60 to 120 mVdec
Volmer equation at such a large applied potential suggests a fast electron-
transfer kinetics on the bulk single-crystal surface. We performed
multistep chronopotentiometry measurements to characterize the
kinetic behavior of OH group insertion. As shown in Fig. 2D, the cur-
rent densities showa rapid response to the applied potential and remain
